scenes.summary: Dorian reflects on and becomes absorbed by a mysterious book whose influence he cannot escape. He collects nine color-bound copies to match his fluctuating moods, seeing the book’s heroic character as an idealized mirror of his own future life.

scenes.location: His personal chambers (including the locked room)
scenes.summary: After returning from enigmatic absences, Dorian ascends to his locked room where he confronts his own dual images—his youthful self in the mirror versus the corrupted, aging portrait—and finds a perverse pleasure in the contrast between beauty and decay.

characters: Lord Henry (present as an influential companion)
scenes.summary: Dorian hosts lavish dinner parties frequented by celebrated musicians and influential guests. His timeless beauty and cultured manners mesmerize his peers, silencing critics and reinforcing his enigmatic and admired public persona.

In a mood of introspection and philosophical curiosity, Dorian muses on the nature of the senses and advocates a new form of Hedonism that champions passionate, immediate experience over conventional ascetic restrictions.

scenes.location: Religious settings (in his observations at churches)
scenes.summary: Dorian becomes fascinated with the ritualistic grandeur of Roman Catholic ceremonies. He is drawn to the dramatic movements of the priest, the solemnity of the communion, and the eerie beauty that these sacred rites evoke in him.

scenes.location: A private laboratory or study for scent experiments
scenes.summary: Deepening his pursuit of sensual knowledge, Dorian embarks on the study of perfumes. He experiments with distilling exotic oils and burning odorous gums, seeking to decipher the mysterious relationship between scents, moods, and spiritual states.

scenes.location: A long, latticed music room adorned with vivid colors and luxurious décor
scenes.summary: In an atmospheric concert, Dorian presents performances featuring a variety of rare and exotic musical instruments. The unconventional sounds and stirring performances captivate him, feeding his passion for art that celebrates visceral experience.

scenes.location: His personal treasure room or study
scenes.summary: Dorian turns his attention to the allure of precious gems. He meticulously examines and collects jewels—each accompanied by historic and romantic legends—embodying his obsessive quest for eternal beauty and an aesthetic ideal.

scenes.location: A richly appointed gallery or collection room within his home
scenes.summary: Indulging in his passion for fine textiles and ecclesiastical vestments, Dorian studies exquisite embroideries, tapestries, and liturgical garments. These objects of beauty, remnants of a glorious past, serve as temporary escapes from his inner torment.

scenes.location: The locked room and various parts of his mansion (Nottinghamshire)
scenes.summary: Haunted by the secret portrait that reveals his inner corruption, Dorian alternately loathes and cherishes it. His anxiety about the potential exposure of his hidden sin forces him to repeatedly check that no one has tampered with it, even during his public appearances.

scenes.location: Various fashionable social settings and private clubs
scenes.summary: Whispers and scandalous rumors swirl around Dorian—ranging from brawls with sailors to associations with nefarious characters. Despite such gossip, his charm, wealth, and polished manners shield him from overt censure, while simultaneously deepening his enigmatic allure.

scenes.location: The picture gallery of his country house in Nottinghamshire
scenes.summary: As he strolls among ancestral portraits, Dorian reflects on his lineage and the decadent lives of his forebears. He ponders whether the sins and passions of the past have become an intrinsic part of his nature, contributing to his own moral decline.

scenes.location: A private, contemplative space (likely his study)
scenes.summary: In a culminating act of introspection, Dorian re-reads a fantastic and decadent chapter from the book that has poisoned his soul. Immersed in comparisons with legendary figures of luxury, sin, and artistic excess, he finally acknowledges that his life—a blend of beauty and horror—has been irreversibly tainted by that very book.

characters: Giambattista Cibo (who mockingly assumed the name Innocent)
Pietro Barbi (known as Paul the Second)
Anne de Joyeuse (Admiral of France, as portrayed at the costume ball)
Duke de Valentinois (son of Alexander VI)
Charles the Rash (last Duke of Burgundy)
Lord Henry (present as an influential companion)
Lady Hamilton (Dorian Gray’s mother, referred to by her features)
